Hiya, Chris

Thank you very much for your reply. I don't mind a bit that yo=
u've 
selectively replied - any help is most welcome!

Get/Set tests are a =
pain, but I can indeed see that they're useful. 
In fact, they turned up tw=
o of the issues that JUnit's found for me, 
by exposing copy/paste errors. =
I haven't seen TestUtil before, but it 
sounds interesting - I'll have a lo=
ok at that. Have you used it 
yourself?

The classes and methods (outside t=
he get/sets) are indeed typically 
quite large. Some of this is just becaus=
e the DTO, Domain object and 
Bean perforce contain all the properties and =
their get/sets, which 
seems unavoidable to me. 
But the Service classes an=
d their methods are also large - For 
example, a service update method woul=
d contain code to check the 
values the user passes in, convert the incomin=
g values to the proper 
format, obtain the object they want to update, upda=
te that with each 
value passed in, validate the updated object, apply any =
rules to it, 
and return a message or a generated SOAPBean. These chunks of=
 work 
are typically extracted into separate methods, (at least, they are i=
n 
my code, so I can both reuse them and only test them once) but even 
so,=
 they're considerably larger than 10 lines...
Sounds like this is an area w=
e should look into in more detail - 
thank you!

We are indeed not doing TD=
D, basically because we don't know how! The 
original aim was to work that =
way, but nobody could see how to do it. 
Thank you for the link to the Sque=
ak code - I will have a look at 
that, and hopefully it'll give us some poi=
nters.

Thank very much for your help,
Cheers
Tracey
